questions.stem: In horses, ringworm (dermatophytosis) is BEST described as:

options.label: A
options.text: A deep systemic fungal infection commonly affecting internal organs

options.label: B
options.text: A superficial fungal infection affecting skin, hair, and other keratinized structures

options.label: C
options.text: A viral disease of the integumentary system that causes pustules

options.label: D
options.text: A bacterial cellulitis that spreads via lymphatics

questions.explanation: Equine ringworm is a superficial fungal infection affecting skin, hair, and other keratinized structures. It does not typically cause deep systemic mycosis (A), viral pustules (C), or bacterial cellulitis (D).

questions.stem: The primary dermatophyte species causing ringworm in horses are:

options.label: A
options.text: Trichophyton equinum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes

options.label: B
options.text: Candida albicans and Malassezia pachydermatis

options.label: C
options.text: Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus equi

options.label: D
options.text: Aspergillus fumigatus and Cryptococcus neoformans

questions.explanation: The primary causative dermatophytes in horses are *Trichophyton equinum* and *T. mentagrophytes*; *Nannizzia gypsea* and *Microsporum canis* may also occur. The other organisms listed (B–D) are yeasts, bacteria, or systemic fungi not typically responsible for equine ringworm.

questions.stem: Dermatophytes in equine ringworm primarily feed on:

options.label: A
options.text: Collagen and elastin in deep dermis

options.label: B
options.text: Keratin in hair shafts and superficial skin

options.label: C
options.text: Lipids in sebaceous secretions

options.label: D
options.text: Melanin pigment in the epidermis

questions.explanation: Dermatophytes feed on keratin in hair shafts and superficial stratum corneum, explaining their superficial, keratin-associated lesions. Collagen and elastin (A), lipids (C), and melanin (D) are not their primary substrates.

questions.stem: Which route of transmission is MOST important for equine ringworm?

options.label: A
options.text: Aerosol spread over long distances

options.label: B
options.text: Vertical transmission in utero

options.label: C
options.text: Direct contact with infected animals or contaminated objects (fomites)

options.label: D
options.text: Transplacental migration of larvae

questions.explanation: Transmission occurs via direct contact with infected animals or indirectly via contaminated grooming tools, tack, stalls, and environment. Aerosol spread (A), vertical transmission (B), and larval migration (D) are not characteristic for dermatophytosis.

questions.stem: Which statement regarding the depth of infection in typical equine ringworm is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: It usually causes deep systemic invasion and fungemia

options.label: B
options.text: It remains superficial, affecting skin and hair without deep systemic spread

options.label: C
options.text: It always invades bone marrow

options.label: D
options.text: It only affects hooves and keratinized laminae

questions.explanation: In horses, ringworm classically remains a superficial infection of skin and hair, without deep systemic spread. Deep invasion and fungemia (A, C) or exclusive hoof involvement (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: Which horses are at higher risk of developing ringworm?

options.label: A
options.text: Only geriatrics over 20 years of age

options.label: B
options.text: Only foals under 6 months

options.label: C
options.text: Younger horses or those with compromised skin or immune function

options.label: D
options.text: Only stallions and intact males

questions.explanation: All ages can be infected, but younger horses and those with compromised skin or immune status have higher risk. It is not limited strictly to geriatrics (A), foals (B), or stallions (D).

questions.stem: A typical ringworm lesion in horses appears as:

options.label: A
options.text: Circular or irregular areas of alopecia with scaling, crusting, and broken hairs

options.label: B
options.text: Diffuse hyperpigmentation without hair loss

options.label: C
options.text: Deep ulcerative lesions with draining tracts

options.label: D
options.text: Vesicles and bullae along mucocutaneous junctions

questions.explanation: Typical lesions are circular or irregular alopecic areas with broken hairs, scaling, crusting, and mild erythema. Diffuse hyperpigmentation (B), deep draining tracts (C), or vesicles/bullae at mucocutaneous junctions (D) describe other dermatologic conditions.

questions.stem: Which regions are commonly involved early in equine ringworm?

options.label: A
options.text: Girth and saddle regions, with possible spread to neck, flanks, chest, and head

options.label: B
options.text: Sole and frog only

options.label: C
options.text: Perineum and ventral abdomen only

options.label: D
options.text: Eyelids and nostrils exclusively

questions.explanation: The girth and saddle regions (“girth itch”) are commonly affected initially, with possible spread to neck, flanks, chest, and head. The other locations (B–D) are less classic for equine ringworm.

questions.stem: Regarding zoonotic potential, ringworm in horses:

options.label: A
options.text: Has no zoonotic risk

options.label: B
options.text: Is zoonotic in some cases and can spread from horses to humans

options.label: C
options.text: Only spreads from humans to horses, not the reverse

options.label: D
options.text: Is only zoonotic in immunocompromised horses

questions.explanation: Many equine dermatophytes are zoonotic, and infection can spread from horses to humans, so biosecurity is important. It is not completely non-zoonotic (A), not only human-to-horse (C), and “zoonotic only in immunocompromised horses” (D) is misframed.

questions.stem: Which environmental and management factor MOST increases the risk of ringworm in a stable?

options.label: A
options.text: Dry, well-ventilated stalls and individual grooming kits

options.label: B
options.text: Damp, humid conditions with shared tack and grooming tools

options.label: C
options.text: Strict isolation of new arrivals and regular disinfection

options.label: D
options.text: Daily sun exposure and open-air turnout

questions.explanation: Damp, humid environments with shared, poorly cleaned tack and grooming tools favor dermatophyte persistence and spread. Dry, well-managed stables (A) and strong biosecurity (C, D) reduce risk.

questions.stem: Which laboratory method is considered the MOST accurate for confirming dermatophytosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Bacterial culture of pus from lesions

options.label: B
options.text: Fungal culture of hairs and skin scrapings from active lesion margins

options.label: C
options.text: Serum antibody titers against dermatophytes

options.label: D
options.text: Fecal flotation and sedimentation

questions.explanation: Fungal culture of hairs and skin scrapings from active lesion margins is the most accurate diagnostic method for dermatophytosis. Bacterial culture (A), antibody titers (C), and fecal tests (D) are not standard for ringworm diagnosis.

questions.stem: When collecting samples for fungal culture in suspected ringworm:

options.label: A
options.text: Lesions should be scrubbed thoroughly with alcohol before sampling

options.label: B
options.text: Sampling should focus on recently active margins, broken hairs, and crusts

options.label: C
options.text: Only intact, normal hair should be sampled

options.label: D
options.text: Only blood samples are needed

questions.explanation: Sampling should include the active lesion margin, broken hairs, crusts, and scales; alcohol scrubbing before sampling (A) can reduce culture yield. Normal hair (C) and blood (D) are not ideal samples.

questions.stem: Which condition is a key differential diagnosis for equine ringworm because it can produce similar superficial skin lesions?

options.label: A
options.text: Equine protozoal myeloencephalitis

options.label: B
options.text: Dermatophilosis (rain scald)

options.label: C
options.text: Strangles

options.label: D
options.text: Equine influenza

questions.explanation: Dermatophilosis (rain scald) can clinically resemble ringworm with crusting and alopecia, making it an important differential. The other conditions (A, C, D) primarily affect other systems or present differently.

questions.stem: Which topical treatment is PREFERRED as a whole-body, leave-on rinse for managing equine ringworm?

options.label: A
options.text: Dilute bleach solution applied daily

options.label: B
options.text: Lime sulfur (1:16), enilconazole (1:100), or 2% miconazole/2% chlorhexidine shampoo

options.label: C
options.text: Plain water rinses with no medicated product

options.label: D
options.text: High-concentration iodine scrub

questions.explanation: Preferred topical whole-body, leave-on therapies include lime sulfur (1:16), enilconazole (1:100), or 2% miconazole/2% chlorhexidine shampoo. Bleach (A, C) is irritating and not first-line, and plain water (C) lacks antifungal activity.

questions.stem: Why are systemic oral antifungals generally avoided in treating ringworm in horses?

options.label: A
options.text: They are ineffective against dermatophytes

options.label: B
options.text: They are usually not needed and can be costly or have more side effects

options.label: C
options.text: They cause rapid recurrence of infection

options.label: D
options.text: They are only approved for use in cattle

questions.explanation: Systemic oral antifungals are often avoided due to cost, potential adverse effects, and the fact that most equine ringworm cases respond to topical therapy and environmental management. They are not inherently ineffective (A) and do not cause recurrence (C), nor are they restricted to cattle (D).

questions.stem: Which advice regarding bleach use in ringworm cases is MOST appropriate?

options.label: A
options.text: Bleach is the first-line topical therapy for horses and tack

options.label: B
options.text: Bleach is avoided because it is irritating and poses human health risks

options.label: C
options.text: Bleach must be applied undiluted directly to lesions

options.label: D
options.text: Bleach is only used on wounds, not on equipment

questions.explanation: Bleach is discouraged directly on horses because it is irritating and a human health hazard; other disinfectants are preferred. It is not first-line (A), should not be used undiluted on lesions (C), and is not specifically limited to wounds (D).

questions.stem: A major complication of untreated or poorly controlled ringworm in a stable is:

options.label: A
options.text: Rapid progression to systemic mycosis

options.label: B
options.text: Widespread infection of other horses due to environmental contamination

options.label: C
options.text: Irreversible hair follicle destruction in all cases

options.label: D
options.text: Permanent scarring and hoof deformity in all horses

questions.explanation: The major complication is spread to other horses (and sometimes other species) due to environmental spore contamination. Systemic mycosis (A), universal follicle destruction (C), and hoof deformities (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: Which general statement about the prognosis of equine ringworm is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Prognosis is poor even with treatment

options.label: B
options.text: Prognosis is generally good with appropriate topical therapy and hygiene

options.label: C
options.text: Prognosis is always guarded due to systemic spread

options.label: D
options.text: Prognosis is unknown because the disease is rare

questions.explanation: With proper topical therapy and good hygiene, prognosis is generally good, and many cases may even self-resolve as immunity develops. It is not usually poor (A), consistently guarded due to systemic spread (C), or rare and unknown (D).

questions.stem: Which preventive measure is MOST important to limit ringworm spread in a boarding facility?

options.label: A
options.text: Feeding high-energy diets to boost immunity

options.label: B
options.text: Avoiding clipper use during winter

options.label: C
options.text: Avoiding shared tack and grooming tools without proper cleaning and disinfection

options.label: D
options.text: Eliminating turnout time

questions.explanation: Avoiding shared tack and grooming tools without thorough cleaning/disinfection is critical to prevent stable-wide transmission. Diet (A), avoiding clipping (B), or eliminating turnout (D) are less directly relevant.

questions.stem: Which statement BEST summarizes environmental control for ringworm?

options.label: A
options.text: Spores die quickly in the environment and do not require stable decontamination

options.label: B
options.text: Spores persist long term on wood, soil, and tack, so environmental cleaning is as important as treating the horse

options.label: C
options.text: Only the horse’s skin needs treatment; the stall environment is irrelevant

options.label: D
options.text: Environmental control is unnecessary once lesions are crusted

questions.explanation: Dermatophyte spores persist for long periods on wood, soil, and tack, so environmental decontamination is as important as treating the horse. It is incorrect to assume they die quickly (A), that the environment is irrelevant (C), or that control is unnecessary once crusting occurs (D).
